dialogues.speaker: ALEX

dialogues.text: Cut the shit, sonny, and get out of here before you get yourself in some very serious trouble. He rocks the giant phallus which has a special weight swi inside causing it to swing up and down an eccentric motio

dialogues.speaker: CATLADY
dialogues.text: I told you to leave it alone. Now get out of here before I throw you out, wretched slummy bedbug. I'll teach you breaking into real people's houses. Get out! She grabs up a bust of Beethoven and rushes at Alex. He g giant phallic sculpture. Circling, Alex fends off her mad rushes with skilful jabs giant phallus. She ducks under and clobbers him with the heavy bust of B He goes down, pulling her off balance and they both wind floor. In the struggle, Alex bashes her with the phallus. Distant Police sirens. He exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex rushes out. Dim and the others are waiting.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Come on. Let's go, the police are coming.

dialogues.speaker: DIM
dialogues.text: One minoota, droogie. Dim smashes Alex in the face with a full milk bottle. He down. The others run away, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (screaming) You bastards... bastards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inspector takes out cigarette and lights up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Right , Tom, we'll have to our little friend, Alex, here that we know the law, too, but that knowing the law isn't everything. He nods to Fatneck.

dialogues.speaker: FATNECK
dialogues.text: That's a nasty cut you've got there, little Alex. Spoils... all your beauty. Who gave you that then... eh... eh... He presses Alex's nose, inflicting great pain. Alex sinks knees.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Ow... what's that for, you bastard?

dialogues.speaker: FATNECK
dialogues.text: That was for your lady victim. You ghastly wretched scoundrel. Alex grabs his balls. Alex is beaten by the other Cop. Inspector exits to outside office where Sergeant sits, si cup of tea. Deltoid has just entered.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Sergeant.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Sir.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Ah, good evening, Mr. Deltoid.

dialogues.speaker: DELTOID
dialogues.text: Evening, Inspector.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Would you like your tea now, sir?

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: No, thank you, Sergeant. We'll have it later. May I have some paper towels, please.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: We're interrogating the prisoner now. Perhaps you'd care to come inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you very much They move into Interrogation Room. Alex is on the floor in the corner covered with blood.

dialogues.speaker: DELTOID
dialogues.text: Evening, Sergeant. Evening, all. Dear, dear, this boy does look a mess, doesn't he? Just look at the state of him.

dialogues.speaker: FATNECK
dialogues.text: Love's young nightmare like.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Violence makes violence. He resisted his lawful arrestors.

dialogues.speaker: DELTOID
dialogues.text: Well, it's happened, Alex boy, yes. Just as I thought it would, yes. Dear, dear, dear. Well, this is the end of the line for me... the end of the line, yes.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: It wasn't me, brother, sir. Speak up for me, sir, for I'm not so bad. I was led on by the treachery of others, sir.

dialogues.speaker: INSPECTOR
dialogues.text: Sings the roof off lovely, he does that.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: And where are my stinking traitorous droogs. Get them before the get away. It was all their idea, brothers. They forced me to do it. I'm innocent.

dialogues.speaker: DELTOID
dialogues.text: You are now a murderer, little Alex. A murderer, yes.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Not true, sir. It was only a slight tolchock. She was breathing, I swear it.

dialogues.speaker: DELTOID
dialogues.text: I've just come back from the hospital. Your victim has died.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: You try to frighten me, sir, admit so, sir. This is some new form of torture. Say it, brother, sir.

dialogues.speaker: DELTOID
dialogues.text: It will be your own torture. I hope to God it will torture you to madness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you'd care to give him a bash in the chops, sir. Don't mind us. We'll hold him down. He must be a great disappointment to you, sir. Deltoid spits in Alex's face.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: This is the real weepy and like tragic part of the story beginning, O my brothers and only friends. After a trial with judges and a jury, and some very hard words spoken against your friend and humble narrator, he was sentenced to 14 years in Staja No. 84F among smelly perverts and hardened prestoopnicks, the shock sending my dadda beating his bruised and kroovy rookas against unfair Bog in his Heaven, and my mom, boohoohooing in her mother's grief as her only child and son of her bosom, like letting everybody down real horrorshow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bell rings and a Warder goes and unlocks first a wooden then a barred door.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Morning. One up from Thames, Mister.

dialogues.speaker: WARDER
dialogues.text: One in from Thames, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Right. Open up, Mister.

dialogues.speaker: WARDER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. He opens door and steps back. Alex and another Warden mov Reception desk.

dialogues.speaker: WARDER
dialogues.text: Good morning, sir. Committal sheet.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: (who shouts everything) Thank you, Mister. He signs sheet.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexander de Large.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: You are now in H.M. Prison Parkmoor and from this moment you will address all prison officers as sir! Name?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Alexander de Large, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Crime?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Murder, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Right. Take the cuffs off him, Mister. The cuffs are removed.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: You are now 655321 and it is your duty to memorise that number. He hands clipboard back to Warder.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Thank you Mister. Well done.

dialogues.speaker: WARDER
dialogues.text: Thank you, chief.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Let the officer out. Officer exits.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Right. Empty your pockets! Alex moves to desk and leans forward.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Are you able to see that white line painted on the floor directly behind you,

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Then your toes belong on the other side of iti!!

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right carry on. Alex tosses a bar of chocolate on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Pick that up and put it down properly. Alex does so, and continues to empty his pockets. Alex signs.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: One half bar of chocolate. One bunch of keys on white metal ring. One packet of cigarettes. Two plastic ball pens - one black, one red. One pocket comb - black plastic. One address book - imitation red leather. One ten penny piece. One white metal wristlet watch, "Timawrist" on a white metal expanding bracelet. Anything else in your pockets?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Right. Sign here for your valuable property.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: The chocolate and cigarettes you brought in - you lose that as you are now convicted. Now go over to the table and get undressed. Alex walks to table and undresses. Chief Guard moves to t his clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Now then, were you in Police custody this morning?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CHECK-IN
dialogues.text: One jacket - blue pinstripe.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Prison custody?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Yes, sir On remnd, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CHECK-IN
dialogues.text: One neck tie - blue.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Religion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cc of E, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Do you mean Church of England?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, Church of England, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Brown hair, is it?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Fair hair, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Blue eyes?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Blue eyes, yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Do you wear eye glasses or contact lenses?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CHECK-IN
dialogues.text: One shirt - blue, collar attached.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Have you been receiving medical treatment for any serious illness?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CHECK-IN
dialogues.text: One pair of boots - black leather, zippered, worn.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Have you ever had any mental illness?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Do you wear any false teeth or false limbs?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CHECK-IN
dialogues.text: One pair of trousers - blue pinstriped.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Have you ever had any attacks of fainting or dizziness?  Chief Guard

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CHECK-IN
dialogues.text: One pair of socks - black.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Are you an Epileptic?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CHECK-IN
dialogues.text: One pair of underpants - white with blue waistband.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Are you now, or ever have been, a homosexual?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Right. The mothballs, Mister.

dialogues.speaker: CHECK-IN
dialogues.text: Mothballs, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Now then. Face the wall. Bend over and touch your toes. inspects Alex's anus with a penlight.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Mmmmmmm... any venereal disease?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Crabs?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Lice?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Through there for a bath.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Priest in pulpit big rough state-proper type. Convict audience. Alex sits apart tending an overhead projector.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: I ask you friends. What's it going to be then? Is it going to be in and out of institutions like this?0r more in then out for most of you? Or are you going to attend the divine word and realise the punishment that awaits unrepentant sinners in the next world as well as this. A lot of Idiots you are, selling your birthright for a saucer of cold porridge. The urge to live easy. I ask you friends, is it worth it? When we have undeniable proof - yes, my friends, incontrovertible evidence that Hell exists. I know, I know, my friends. I have been informed in visions that there is a place darker than any prison, hotter than any human flame of fire, where unrepentant criminals, sinners like yourselves... A convict burps. All laugh.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Don't you laugh, damn you, don't you laugh. I say like yourselves - scream in endless and unendurable agony. Their nostrils choked with the smell of filth, their mouths crammed with burning ordure. Their skins rotting and peeling. A fireball spinning in their screaming guts. I know... oh yes, I know. A convict lets rip some lip music - prrrrrrrp. There is l Chief Guard moves forward - points.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: I saw you, 920537. I saw you.

dialogues.speaker: CONVICT
dialogues.text: Up yours, mate.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Just you wait, 744678. One on the turnip coming up for you.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Quiet, my friends. Quiet. Quiet, I say. We will now sing Hymn 258 in the Prisoner's Hymnal. Piano starts up and Alex starts up overhead projector wh displays the words of the hymn.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Show a little reverence, you bastards. Quiet! Convicts and all start to sing.

dialogues.speaker: SINGING
dialogues.text: I was a wandering sheep. I did not love...

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Sing up damn you. Louder, sing up.

dialogues.speaker: SINGING
dialogues.text: the fold I did not love my shepherd's voice. I would not be controlled.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Come on, sing up, damn you.

dialogues.speaker: SINGING
dialogues.text: I was a wayward child I did not love my home I did not love my father's voice I loved afar to roam.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It had not been edifying, indeed not, being in this hell hole and human zoo for two years now, being kicked and tolchocked by brutal warders, and meeting leering criminals and perverts ready to dribble all over a lucious young malchick like your story-teller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex reading the Bible.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It was my rabbit to help the prison charlie with the Sunday service. He was a bolshy great burly bastard, but he was very fond of myself, me being very young, and also now very interested in the big book. Priest walks by and nods pleasantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It had been arranged by the prison charlie, as part of my further education to read him the Bible. I didn't so much like the latter part of the book which is more like all preachy talking, than fighting and the old in-out. I liked the parts where these old yahoodies tolchock each other and then drink their Hebrew vino and, then getting on to the bed with their wives' handmaidens. That kept me going.

dialogues.speaker: BIBLE FANTASY
dialogues.text: Biblical fighting shot. Alex slashing away. Blood spurtin

dialogues.speaker: HANDMAIDEN FANTASY IN TENT
dialogues.text: Alex lying with three semi-nude handmaidens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ being whipped on by Alex, dressed as a Legionary.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Move on there. Move on.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I read all about the scourging and the crowning with thorns and all that, and I could viddy myself helping in and even taking charge of the tolchocking and the nailing in, being dressed in the height of Roman fashion.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE LIBRARY
dialogues.text: Alex sits with his eyes closed. Priest comes over and squeezes his shoulder. Alex looks up at him and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: (reading from Alex's Bible) Seek not to be like evil men, neither desire to be with them, because their minds studieth robberies and their lips speak deceits.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: If thou lose hope being weary in the days of distress, thy strength shall be diminished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, my boy, fine, fine.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Father, I have tried, have I not?

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: You have, my son.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I've done my best, have I not?

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Indeed.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: And, Father, I've never been guilty of any institutional infractions, have I?

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: You certainly have not, 655321. You've been very helpful, and you've shown a genuine desire to reform.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Father - may I ask you a question in private?

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Certainly, my son, certainly. Is there something troubling you, my son? Don't be shy to speak up. Remember, I know all the urges that can trouble young men deprived of the society of women.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: No Father. It's nothing like that, Father. It's about this new thing they're all talking about. About this new treatment that you out of prison in no time at all and makes sure you never get back in again.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Where did you hear about this? Whose been talking about these things?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: These things get around, Father. Two Warders talk as it might be, and somebody can't help overhearing what they say. Then somebody picks up a scrap of newspaper in the workshops and the newspaper tells all about it. How about putting me in for this new treatment, Father?

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: I take it you are referring to the Ludovico Technique?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what it's called, Father, all I know is that it gets you out quickly and makes sure that you never get in again.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: That's not proven, 655321. In fact, it is only in the experimental stage at this moment .

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: But it is being used, isn't it, Father?

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: It has not been used yet in this prison. The Governor has grave doubts about it and I have heard that there are very serious dangers involved.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I don't care about the danger, Father. I just want to be good. I want for the rest of my life to be one act of goodness.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: The question is weather or not this technique really makes a man good. Goodness comes from within. Goodness is chosen. When a man cannot chose, he ceases to be a man.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I don't understand about the whys and wherefores, Father. I only know I want to be good.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Be patient, my son, and put your trust in the Lord.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Instruct thy son and he shall refresh thee and shall give delight to thy soul.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Amen. They cross themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prisoners walking in circles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guards stand either side of cell doors. Chief Guard with Governor, Minister and entourage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: All present and correct, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Right. All present and correct, sir.

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR
dialogues.text: Very good, Chief. They inspect cells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chief Guard

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Leave to carry on, sir, please?

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR
dialogues.text: Carry on, Chief.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Sir.

dialogues.speaker: YARD
dialogues.text: comes out of door.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Right, pay attention. I want you in two lines. Up against that wall facing this way. Go on move! Hurry up about it and stop talking. The men line up. Chief Guard moves back to door and comes attention.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Ready for inspection, sir. He stands back and salutes as Governor, Minister and ento enter and walk along line of men.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: How many to a cell?

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR
dialogues.text: Four in this block, sir.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: Cram criminals together and what do you get - concentrated criminality... crime in the midst of punishment.

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR
dialogues.text: I agree, sir. What we need are larger prisons. More money.  Alex seizes

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: Not a chance, my dear fellow. The Ggovernment can't be concerned any longer with outmoded penological theories. Soon we may be needing all of out prison space for political offenders. Common criminals like these are best dealt with on a purely curative basis. Kill the criminal reflex that's all. Full implementation in a year's time. Punishment means nothing to them, you can see that... they enjoy their so-called punishment. his chance as they pass by.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: You're absolutely right, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Shut your bleedin' hole!!!

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: Who said that?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I did, sir.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: What crime did you commit.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: The accidental killing of a person, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: He brutally murdered a woman, sir, in furtherence of theft. 14 years... sir!

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: Excellent. He's enterprising, aggressive, outgoing. Young. Bold. Viscous. He'll do.

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR
dialogues.text: Well, fine... we could still look at C- Block.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: No, no, no. That's enough. He's perfect. I want his records sent to me. This vicious young hoodlum will be transformed out of all recognition.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Thank you very much for this chance, sir.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: Let's hope you make the most of it, my boy.

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR
dialogues.text: Shall we go to my office?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Governor seated at his desk. There is a knock on the door

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR
dialogues.text: Come in. Door opens. Chief Guard enters with Alex.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Sir, 655321, sir.

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR
dialogues.text: Very good, Chief. Chief Guard turns to Alex.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Forward to the white line, toes behind it. Full name and number to the Governor. Chief Guard closes door.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Alexander de Large, sir. 655321, sir. The Governor takes off his glasses.

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR
dialogues.text: I don't suppose you know who that was this morning, do you? That was no less a personage than the Minister of the Interior and what they call a very new broom. Well, these new ridiculous ideas have come at last, and orders are orders, though I may say to you in confidence that I do not approve. An eye for an eye, I say, if someone hits you, you hit back, do you not? Why then should not the State very severely hit by you brutal offenders not hit back also? But the new view is to say no. The new view is that we turn the bad into good. All of which seems to be grossly unjust. Hmmmmmm.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Sir...

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Shut your filthy hole, you scum!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are to be reformed. Tomorrow you go to this man, Brodsky. You will be leaving here. You will be transferred to the Ludovico Medical Facility. It is believed that you will be able to leave State custody in a little over a fortnight. I suppose that prospect pleases you?

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Answer when the Governor asks you a question you filthy young swine!

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Oh yes, sir. Thank you very much, sir. I've done my best here I really have, sir. I'm very grateful to all concerned.

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR
dialogues.text: Sign this - where it's marked. Alex turns the paper to read it.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Don't read it - sign it!

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR
dialogues.text: It says that you are willing to have the residue of your sentence commuted to the Ludovico treatment. Alex signs. Governor gathers up papers. Alex dots the last "i" and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: The next morning I was taken to the Ludovico Medical Facility, outside the town centre, and I felt a malenky bit sad having to say goodbye to the old Staja, as you always will when you leave a place you've like gotten used to. Chief Guard briskly leads the way for Alex and escort. Th into reception hall where the Doctor stands.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: (shouting like an RSM) Right. Halt the prisoner. Good morning, sir, I'm Chief Officer Barnes. I've got 655321 on a transfer from Parkmoor to the Ludovico Centre, sir!

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Good morning, we've been expecting you. I'm Dr. Alcott.  Chief Guard checks the name from his clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Yes, Dr. Alcott. Are you prepared to accept the prisoner, sir?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Yes, of course.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Well, I wonder if you'd mind signing these transfer documents, sir. Doctor signs.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. There, sir... there, and there, sir... and there. Thank you, sir. Prison escort move forward. Halt. Excuse me, sir. Is that the officer that is to take charge of the prisoner, sir? Doctor nods. Officer steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
dialogues.text: If I might offer a word of advice, Doc. You'll have to watch this one. A right brutal bastard he has been, and will be again. In spite all his sucking up to the prison Chaplain and reading the Bible.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Oh, I think we can manage things. Charlie, will you show the young man to his room now.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Right, sir. Come this way, please. Alex exits with Officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex finishing breakfast tray in bed. Room bright and cheery. Dr. Branom, a tall woman in her fifties, enters with nurs carrying a sterile tray.

dialogues.speaker: DR. BRANOM
dialogues.text: (very briskly) Good morning, Alex, my name is Dr. Branom. I'm Doctor Brodsky's assistant.  She removes She inserts

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Good Morning, Missus. Lovely day, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: DR. BRANOM
dialogues.text: Indeed it is. May I take this his tray.

dialogues.speaker: DR. BRANOM
dialogues.text: How're you feeling this morning?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Fine... fine.

dialogues.speaker: DR. BRANOM
dialogues.text: Good. In a few minutes, you'll meeting Dr. Brodsky and we'll begin your treatment. You're a very lucky boy to have been chosen.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I realise all that, Missus, and I'm very grateful to all concerned.

dialogues.speaker: DR. BRANOM
dialogues.text: We're going to friends now, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I hope so, Missus. a needle into the medicine vial.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's the hypo for then? Going to send me to sleep?

dialogues.speaker: DR. BRANOM
dialogues.text: Oh no, nothing of the sort.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Vitamins will it be then?

dialogues.speaker: DR. BRANOM
dialogues.text: Something like that. You are a little undernourished, so after each meal were going to give you a shot. Roll over on your right side please, loosen your pajama pants and pull them half-way down. He does, somewhat reluctanly. She gives him a shot in the

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: What exactly is the treatment here going to be then?

dialogues.speaker: DR. BRANOM
dialogues.text: It's quite simple really. Were just going to show you some films.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean like going to the pictures?

dialogues.speaker: DR. BRANOM
dialogues.text: Something like that.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Well, that's good. I like to viddy the old films now and again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Auditorium setting. Alex is bound in a examination chair of a large video screen. A white-coated Technician is str Alex's head to a medical device. He then carefully attaches the eyelid locking to Alex's e

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And viddy films I would. Where I was taken to, brothers, was like no cine I'd been in before. I was bound up in a straight- jacket and my guliver was strapped to a headrest with like wires running away from it. Then they clamped like lidlocks on my eyes so I could not shut them no matter how hard I tried. It seemed a bit crazy to me, but I let them get on with what they wanted to get on with. If I was to be a free young malchick in a fortnight's time, I would put up with much in the meantime, my brothers. At the back of the auditorium are ten or fifteen solemn m Professionals in white coats watching the proceedings and occasionally taking notes. A film begins showing on the s The Technician drops eyedrops into Alex's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLENCE FILM
dialogues.text: Man being beaten by four toughs wearing white. Punches, kicks, grunts, blood.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: So far the first film was a very good professional piece of cine, looked like it was done in Hollywood. Screams, moans, kicks, punches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sounds were real horroshow. You could slooshy the screams and moans very realistic and you could even get the heavy breathing and panting of the tolchocking malchicks at the same time. And then, what do you know, soon our dear old friend, the red, red vino on tap. The same in all places like it's put out by the same big firm, began to flow. It was beautiful. It's funny how the colors of the real world only seem really real when you viddy them on a screen. More kicks, punches, groans, thumps. Girl being beaten, raped by six toughs. Screams, music, laughing, grunts, heavy breathing.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Now all the time I was watching this, I was beginning to get very aware of like not feeling all that well, but I tried to forget this, concentrating on the next film, which jumped right away on a young devotchka, who was being given the old in- out, in-out, first by one malchick, then another, then another. This seemed real, very real, though if you thought about it properly you couldn't imagine lewdies actually agreeing to having all this done to them in a film, and if these films were made by the good, or the State, you couldn't imagine them being allowed to take these films, without like interfering with what was going on. Girl being raped.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: When it came to the sixth or seventh malchick, leering and smecking and then going into it, I began to feel really sick. But I could not shut my glazzies and even if I tried to move my glazballs about I still not get out of the line of fire of this picture. Alex squirming and retching. Dr. Brodsky clears his throat and quietly addresses his c seated in the back of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very soon now the drug will cause the subject to experience a death-like paralysis together with deep feelings of terror and helplessness. One of our earlier test subjects described it as being like death, a sense of stifling and drowning, and it is during this period we have found the subject will make his most rewarding associations between his catastrophic experience and environment and the violence he sees. Alex retching violently and struggling against his strait

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Let me be sick... I want to get up. Get me something to be sick in... Stop the film... Please stop it... I can't stand it any more. Stop it please... please.

dialogues.speaker: DR. BRANOM
dialogues.text: Well, that was a very promising start. By my calculations, you should be starting to feel alright again. Yes? Dr. Brodsky's pleased with you. Now tomorrow there'll be two sessions, of course, morning and afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: You mean, I have to viddy two sessions in one day?

dialogues.speaker: DR. BRANOM
dialogues.text: I imagine you'll be feeling a little bit limp by the end of the day. But we have to be hard on you. You have to be cured.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: But it was horrible.

dialogues.speaker: DR. BRANOM
dialogues.text: Well, of course, it was horrible. Violence is a very horrible thing. That's what you're learning now. Your body is learning it.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I just don't understand about feeling sick the way I did. I never used to feel sick before. I used to feel like the very opposite. I mean, doing it or watching it, I used to feel real horrorshow. I just don't understand why, how or what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You felt ill this afternoon because you're getting better. You see, when we're healthy we respond to the presence of the hateful with fear and nausea. You're becoming healthy that's all. By this time tomorrow you'll be healthier still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex retching and screaming - restrained again by a strai jacket.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It was the next day, brothers, and I had truly done my best, morning and afternoon, to play it their way and sit like a horrorshow co-operative malchick in the chair of torture, while they flashed nasty bits of ultra-violence on the screen.; though not on the soundtrack, my brothers. The only sound being music. Then I noticed in all my pain and sickness what music it was that like cracked and boomed. It was Ludwig van - 9th symphony, 4th movement.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Stop it... stop it, please!!! I beg of you!!! It's a sin!!! It's a sin!!! It's a sin, please!!! Brodsky leans forward and turns down the sound.

dialogues.speaker: DR. BRODSKY
dialogues.text: What's all this about sin?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: That!... Using Ludwig van like that! He did no harm to anyone. Beethoven just wrote music.

dialogues.speaker: DR. BRANOM
dialogues.text: Are you referring to the background score?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Yes!!!

dialogues.speaker: DR. BRANOM
dialogues.text: You've heard Beethoven before?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Yes!!!

dialogues.speaker: DR. BRODSKY
dialogues.text: You're keen on music?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Yes!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) What do you think about that, Dr. Brodsky?

dialogues.speaker: DR. BRODSKY
dialogues.text: (softly) It can't be helped. Here's your punishment element perhaps. The Governor ought to be pleased... I'm sorry, Alex, this is for your own good, you'll have to bear with us for a while.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: You needn't take it any further, sir. You've proved to me that all this ultra- violence and killing is wrong and terribly wrong. I've learned my lesson, sir. I see now what I've never seen before I'm cured, praise Bog!

dialogues.speaker: DR. BRODSKY
dialogues.text: You're not cured yet, my boy.

dialogues.speaker: DR. BRODSKY
dialogues.text: You must take your chance boy. The choice has been all yours.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: But, Sir... Missus... I see that it's wrong! It's wrong because it's like against like society. It's wrong because everybody has the right to live and be happy without being tolchocked and knifed.

dialogues.speaker: DR. BRODSKY
dialogues.text: No, no, boy. You really must leave it to us, but be cheerful about it. In less than a fortnight now, you'll be a free man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIP audience including Minister, Junior Minister, Prison Priest, Dr. Branom, Dr. Brodsky. Dressed in street clothes Alex enters led by a white-coat Technician. He is led onto stage and left standing there, blinking in lights. The Minister rises and walks to the front of the auditori

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and Gentlemen, at this point, we introduce the subject himself. He is, as you will perceive, fit and well nourished. He comes straight from as night's sleep and a good breakfast, undrugged, unhypnotized. Tomorrow, we send him with confidence out into the world again, as decent a lad as you would meet on a May morning. What a change is here, Ladies and Gentlemen, from the wretched hoodlum the state committed to unprofitable punishment some two years ago, unchanged after two years. Unchanged, do I say - not quite. Prison taught him a false smile, the rubbed hands of hypocrisy, the fawning, greased, obsequious leer. Other vices prison taught him as well as confirming him in those he had long practiced before. Our party promised to restore law and order and to make the streets safe for the ordinary peace loving citizen. This pledge is now about to become a reality. Ladies and Gentlemen, this is an historic moment. The problem of criminal violence is soon to be a thing of the past. But enough of words - actions speak louder than. Action now. Observe all. He returns to his seat and leans close to his Junior Mini

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR MINISTER
dialogues.text: Our necks are out a long way on this, Minister.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: I have complete faith in Brodsky. If the polls are right, we have nothing to lose. Lights are dimmed. Enter Lardface, an elegantly dressed f

dialogues.speaker: LARDFACE
dialogues.text: Hello, heap of dirt. Pooh, you don't wash much do you, judging by the horrible smell.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Why do you say that, brother? I had a shower this morning.

dialogues.speaker: LARDFACE
dialogues.text: Oh, he had a shower this morning. You trying to call me a liar?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: No, brother. What d'you want?

dialogues.speaker: LARDFACE
dialogues.text: What do I want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, brother. I didn't mean any offence.

dialogues.speaker: LARDFACE
dialogues.text: Oh. Oh, you're sorry are you, well you must think I'm awfully stupid. He slaps Alex in the face.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Why did you do that, brither? I've never done wrong to you.

dialogues.speaker: LARDFACE
dialogues.text: You want to know why I did that, well you see - I do that... He stamps on Alex's foot.

dialogues.speaker: LARDFACE
dialogues.text: and this... He pulls Alex's nose.

dialogues.speaker: LARDFACE
dialogues.text: and that... He pulls Alex's ear, pushes him off balance and plants hi his chest.

dialogues.speaker: LARDFACE
dialogues.text: because I don't like you horrible type, do I, and if you want to start something... if you want to start... go on... well, you just start. Please do. Alex retching.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I'm gonna be sick.

dialogues.speaker: LARDFACE
dialogues.text: You're gonna be sick are you?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I wanna be sick.

dialogues.speaker: LARDFACE
dialogues.text: You wanna be sick?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Let me get up.

dialogues.speaker: LARDFACE
dialogues.text: You wanna get up? Well, you've gotta you see... well I want you to lick it. Go on... Lick it. Alex, gagging and coughing, licks the sole of his shoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... And again... Go on!!! Again! There's a good boy.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And, O my brothers, would you believe your faithful friend and long suffering narrator pushed out his red yahzik a mile and a half to lick the grahzny, vonny boots. The horrible killing sickness had wooshed up and turned the like joy of battle into a feeling I was going to snuff it. Minister rises.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: Enough! That will do very well. Thank you. Lardface does leading-man-bows. A smattering of applause.

dialogues.speaker: LARDFACE
dialogues.text: Thank you very much, Ladies and Gentlemen... Thank you. Alex on floor - still retching. A beautiful nude Girl enters. Alex looks up slowly.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: She came towards me with the light like it was the like light of heavenly grace, and the first thing that flashed into my gulliver was that I would like to have her right down there on the floor with the old in-out, real savage. But quick as a shot came the sickness, like a detective that had been watching around the corner and now followed to make his arrest. Alex retching. Minister rises.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: Thank you very much. Thank you my dear. Girl bows and exits to loud applause.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: Not feeling too bad now are you?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (pullimg himself together) No, sir, I feel really great.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was I alright, sir? Did I do well, sir?

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: Fine. Absolutely fine. You see, Ladies and Gentlemen our subject is, you see, impelled towards good by paradoxically being impelled toward evil. The intention to act violently is accompanied by strong feelings of physical distress. To counter these, the subject has to switch to a diametrically opposed attitude. Any questions? Priest rises and moves to Alex.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Choice! The boy has no real choice, has he? Self interest, fear of physical pain drove him to that grotesque act of self abasement. Its insincerity was clearly to be seen. He ceases also to be a creature capable of moral choice.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: Padre, these are subtleties. We are not concerned with motive, with the higher ethics; we are concerned only with cutting down crime. And with relieving the ghastly congestion in our prisons... He will be your true Christian, ready to turn the other cheek. Ready to be crucified rather than crucify, sick to the very heart at the thought even of killing a fly. Reclamation, joy before the angels of God. The point is that it works! Applause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex walking carrying his prison parcel wrapped in brown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma, Pa and Joe the Lodger reading newspapers. Headlines - Alex. Alex enters quietly. Loud radio music from sitting room p anyone from hearing him. He enters his won room which is off the hall.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Hi. Hi. Hi, there my Pee and Em. All three look up startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (to his mother) Hullo love, how are you? (kisses her) Nice to see you, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: PEE
dialogues.text: Hullo lad. What a surprise, good to see you.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Keeping fit then?

dialogues.speaker: PEE
dialogues.text: (very ill at ease) Fine, fine.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Well, how are you then?

dialogues.speaker: PEE
dialogues.text: Oh fine, fine. Keeping out of trouble, you know.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Well - I'm back.

dialogues.speaker: PEE
dialogues.text: (with feigned enthusiasm) Aye. Glad to see you back, lad.

dialogues.speaker: EM
dialogues.text: Why didn't you let us know what was happening, son?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Sorry, Em, I wanted it to be like... a big surprise for you and pee.

dialogues.speaker: PEE
dialogues.text: Well, it's a surprise all right, a bit bewildering too.

dialogues.speaker: EM
dialogues.text: We've only just read about it in the morning papers.

dialogues.speaker: PEE
dialogues.text: Aye. You should have let us know, lad, not that we're not very pleased to see you again. All cured too, eh?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: That's right, Dad they did a great job on my gulliver, I'm completely reformed.  Alex Alex same Alex Alex More

dialogues.speaker: PEE
dialogues.text: Aye.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (looks in the kitchen) Well, still the same old place then, eh?

dialogues.speaker: PEE
dialogues.text: Oh, aye, aye.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (fake whisper) Hey, Dad, there's a strange fella sitting on the sofa there munchy-wunching lomticks of toast.

dialogues.speaker: PEE
dialogues.text: Aye, that's Joe. He... ummmm, lives here now. The lodger. That's what he is... he... he rents your room. confronts Joe.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: How do you do, Joe? Find the room comfortable, do you? No complaints?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I've heard about you. I know what you've done. Breaking the hearts of your poor grieving parents. So you're back? You're back to make a life of misery for your lovely parents, is that it? Well, over my dead corpse you will, because you see, they've let me be more like a son to them than like a lodger. cocks his fist and starts to retch violently, almost at t moment Joe drops back on the couch next to Em.

dialogues.speaker: EM
dialogues.text: Joe! Joe! Don't fight here boys! burps and retches.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Oh, please. Do put your hand over your mouth, it's bloody revolting. violently ill.

dialogues.speaker: PEE
dialogues.text: Well, what's the matter lad, are you feeling alright?

dialogues.speaker: EM
dialogues.text: Dad... It's the treatment. retching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's disgusting. It puts you off your food.

dialogues.speaker: EM
dialogues.text: Leave him be, Joe. It's the treatment.

dialogues.speaker: PEE
dialogues.text: D'you think we should do something?

dialogues.speaker: EM
dialogues.text: Would you like me to make you a nice cup of tea, son?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: No thanks, Mum. It'll pass in a minute... (after a pause) . What have you done with all my own personal things?

dialogues.speaker: PEE
dialogues.text: Well. That was all took away, son, by the Police. New regulation about compensation for the victim.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: What about Basil? Where's my snake?

dialogues.speaker: PEE
dialogues.text: Oh well, he met with like an accident. He passed away. Alex becomes a bit weepy.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: What's gonna happen to me then? I mean that's my room he's in - there's no denying that. This is my home also. What suggestions have you, my Pee and Em, to make?

dialogues.speaker: PEE
dialogues.text: Well, all this needs thinking about, son. I mean we can't very well just kick Joe out... Not just like that, can we? I mean Joe is here doing a job. A contract it is, two years. Well, we made like an arrangement, didn't we Joe? You see, son, Joe's paid next month's rent already so, well, whatever we do in the future, we cant just say to Joe to get out, now can we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, there's much more than that, though. I mean I've got you two to think of. I mean you're more like a mother and father to me. Well, it wouldn't be fair now, would it, for me to go off and leave you two to the tender mercies of this young monster who's been like no real son at all. Look, let him go off and find a room somewhere. Let him learn the errors of his way, and that a bad boy like he's been don't deserve such a good mum and dad as he's had.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Alright. I see how things are now. I've suffered and I've suffered, and I've suffered and everybody wants me to go on suffering.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You've made others suffer. It's only fair that you should suffer proper. You know I've been told everything you've done, sitting here at night round the family table, pretty shocking it was to listen to. It made me real sick, a lot of it did. Now look what you've gone and done to your mother. Em bursts into tears.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: So that's the way it is then, eh? That's the way it is. Right, I'm leaving now, you won't ever viddy me no more. I'll make my own way. Thank you very much. Let it lie heavy on your consciences. Alex exits.

dialogues.speaker: PEE
dialogues.text: (shouting after him) Now don't take it like that son. Em boohoohoos, Joe comforts her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex walks along the Thames embankment still holding his parcel. Tramp enters. The same man beaten by Alex and his gang ea the film.

dialogues.speaker: TRAMP
dialogues.text: Can you spare me some cutter, me brother? Can you spare some cutter, me brother? Alex, without looking at him, reaches in his pocket and some money.

dialogues.speaker: TRAMP
dialogues.text: Oh, thankyou, your honour. The Tramp takes a second look at Alex.

dialogues.speaker: TRAMP
dialogues.text: Jamey Mack! Be the hokey fly! Holy Mother of God! All the Holy Angels and blessed saints in Heaven preserve us. Alex breaks away but the Tramp toddles alongside him.

dialogues.speaker: TRAMP
dialogues.text: I never forget a face! I never forget any face, be God!

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Leave me alone, brother. I've never seen you before. Tramp shouts to other Meths drinkers and Tramps.

dialogues.speaker: TRAMP
dialogues.text: This is the poisonous young swine that near done me in. Him and his friends beat me and kicked me and thumped me. Alex breaks away again.

dialogues.speaker: TRAMP
dialogues.text: Stop him! Stop him! A leg is stuck out and Alex goes down. The tramp swarm al him.

dialogues.speaker: TRAMP
dialogues.text: They laughed at me blood and me moans. This murderous young pig is a prize specimen of the cowardly brutal young. He is in our midst and at our mercy. Give it to him. That's it. Old Tramps begin to beat at Alex.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Then there was like a sea of dirty, smelly old men trying to get at your humble Narrator, with their feeble rookers and horny old claws. It was Old Age having a go at Youth and I daren't do a single solitary thing, 0 my brothers, it being better to be hit at like that, than want to be sick and feel that horrible pain. The Tramp crowd round Alex, shouting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young hooligan... Vagabound... Kill him... Villain... Toad... Bastard... Kick his teeth in... Near killed poor old Jack, he did. Police move in and push off crowd.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Alright, stop it now.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Alright, stop it now. Alright! Come on. Stop breaking the State peace. You naughty boys. Alright, that's enough. Alex looks up.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Oh, no.

dialogues.speaker: DIM
dialogues.text: Well, well, well, well, well, well, well, if it isn't little Alex. Long time no viddy, droog. How goes? Surprised are you?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Impossible... I don't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Evidence of the old glazzies. Nothing up our sleeves. No magic, little Alex? A job for two, who are now of job age. The police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Police Landrover drives up. Alex is pulled out by Georgie and Dim and hustled up a de lane.

dialogues.speaker: DIM
dialogues.text: Come on, Alex. Come for walkies. Hahahahaha.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Come, come, my little droogies. I just don't get this at all. The old days are dead and gone. For what I did in the past I've been punished.

dialogues.speaker: DIM
dialogues.text: Been punished, yeah?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I've been cured.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Been cured, yeah, that was read out to us. The Inspector read all that out to us. He said it was a very good way.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I just don't get this all. It was them that went for me, brothers. You're not on their side and can't be. You can't be Dim. It was someone we fillied with back in the old days... Trying to get his own malenky bit of revenge after all this time. You remember, Dim?

dialogues.speaker: DIM
dialogues.text: Long time, is right. I don't remember them days too horrorshow. Don't call me Dim no more, either. Officer, call me.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: Enough is remembered though, little Alex. Dim and Georgie laugh. They drag Alex to a low water through.

dialogues.speaker: DIM
dialogues.text: This is to make sure you stay cured. Georgie hits Alex in the stomach with his blackjack. Then push his head under the water and methodically start to b with their blackjacks. After a full minute of this, they drag him out, halt-drow

dialogues.speaker: DIM
dialogues.text: (laughing) Be viddying you some more, some time Alex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex stumbles up the road to the entrance gate.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Where was I to go, who had no home and no money. I cried for meself, Home, Home, Home. It was Home I was wanting and it was Home I came to, brothers, not realising in the state I was in, where I was and had been before. Alex stumbles and crawls to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Alexander at his typewriter. Julian a 6'4" - heavyweight weight-lifter lies across an bench working with bar-bells. The door bell rings.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Who on earth could that be?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: I'll see who it is. He goes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Yes, what is it? No reply. He opens the door. Alex falls into the hall.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (barely audible) Help. Help me... Help me... Police. Julian picks him up like a child and carries him into the room.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And would you believe it, O my brothers and only friends, there was your faithful Narrator being held helpless, like a babe in arms, and suddenly realising where I was and why HOME on the gate had looked so familiar. But I knew I was safe. I knew he would not rememeber me for, in those carefree days, I and my so-called droogs wore our maskies which were like real horrorshow disguises.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Frank, I think this young man needs help.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Dear, dear, dear. Whatever happened to you, my boy? Mr. Alexander, now confined to a wheelchair, pushes himse from his desk, and rolls up to Julian. The water drips of clothes. They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: The police... The horrible ghastly Police. They beat me up, sir. The Police beat me up, sir. Mr. Alexander stares at him. It becomes aparent he is ins

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know who you are! Isn't it your picture in the newspapers? Didn't I see you this morning on the video? Are you not the poor victim of this horrible new technique?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, that's exactly who I am, sir... and what I am... a victim, sir. Mr. Alexander becomes frenzied as the speech progresses.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Then, by God, you have been sent here by providence. Tortured in prison, then thrown out to be tortured by the Police. My heart goes out to you, poor, poor boy. Oh, you are not the first to come here in distress. The Police are fond of bringing their victims to the outskirts of this village. But it is providential that you, who are also another kind of victim, should come here. But you're cold and shivering. Julian, draw a bath for this young man.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Certainly, Frank. He carries Alex off.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Thank you very much, sir. God bless you, sir. Alexander bites his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex soaks, eyes closed, in a hot tub. After a while he begins softly singing to himself: "Singi Rain".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Alexander is hunched over the phone, talking in hoars whipsers. The door to the bathroom is right behind him. W speaks Mr. Alexander throws nervous glances over his shou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you, sir, they have turned this young man into something other than a human being. He has no power of choice any more. He's committed to socially acceptable acts, a little machine capable only of good... He can be the most potent weapon imaginable to ensure that the Government is not returned at the next election. The Government's great boast, as you know sir, is the way they have dealt with crime in the last few months. Recruiting brutal young roughs into the police, proposing debilitation and will- sapping techniques of conditioning. Oh, we've seen it all before in other countries The thin end of the wedge. Before we know where we are we shall have the full apparatus of totalitarianism. This young boy is a living witness to these diabolical proposals. The people - the common people - must know... must see! There are rare traditions of liberty to defend. The tradition of liberty means all. The common people will let it go! Oh, yes - they will sell liberty for a quieter life. That is why they must be led, sir, driven... pushed!!! Thank you very much, sir. He'll be here. Trembling with excitement and madness, Mr. Alexander hang phone. His eyes, shiny with anticipation. Then, suddenly, becomes aware of Alex's voice coming from the other side

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex in bath, singing.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I'm singing in the rain, Just singing in the rain...

dialogues.speaker: MR. ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: His face horribly distorted in a Homeric rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex, alone, in complete silence. Eating a large plate of spaghetti. The giant, Julian, appears, carrying Mr. Alexa his wheelchair. He deposits him at the table.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Good evening, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very weird) Good evening.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: It was very kind of you to leave this out for me, sir. There was no-one around when I finished my bath, so I started. I hope that's alright, sir.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: (too loud - voice out of control) Of course. Food alright?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Great, sir. Great.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Try the wine!

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Thank you very much, sir. Cheers Suddenly the thought occurs to Alex that the wine may be or poisoned.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Won't you join me, sir?

dialogues.speaker: MR. ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: No, my health doesn't allow it.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: (to Julian) And you, sir?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: No thank you. Alex, stalling for time, reaches for bottle and reads the

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: 1960, Chateau, Saint Estephe, Medoc, very good brand, sir. He doesn't get a penny's change for his remarks from Alex Julian. He holds the glass up to the light.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Very good colour, sir. Smells mice, too.Very good number, sir. Very good. Here's to it. He downs the glass.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Very refreshing, sir, very refreshing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very arch) I'm so pleased you appreciate good wine. Have another glass!

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: My wife... Alex freezes.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: used to do everything for me and leave me to my writing.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Your wife, sir? Has she gone away?

dialogues.speaker: MR. ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: No. She's dead!

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to hear about that, sir. His face contorted in rage.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: She was very badly raped, you see. We were assaulted by a gang of vicious young hooligans in this house, in this very room you're sitting in now. I was left a helpless cripple. The doctors said it was Pneumonia, because it happened some months later during the 'flu epidemic. The doctors told me it was Pneumonia, but I knew what it was. A victim of the modern age, poor, poor girl. Suddenly his mood changes. He wheels right up to Alex.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: And now you, another victim of the modern age. But you can be helped. I phoned some friends while you were having a bath.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Phoned some friends, sir?

dialogues.speaker: MR. ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Yes. They want to help.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Help me, sir?

dialogues.speaker: MR. ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are they, sir?

dialogues.speaker: MR. ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: They're very, very important people and they're interested in you. Bell rings. Julian rises,

dialogues.speaker: MR. ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Julian. This will be these people now. Alex gets up.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Look, sir. I'm sorry to have troubled you. I think I ought to be going, sir. Julian bars the way.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: No, no my boy. No trouble at all. Alex slowly sits.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Have another glass of wine. He pours. Alex picks up glass and takes a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolin and Rubinstein enter with Julian.

dialogues.speaker: DOLIN
dialogues.text: (genial) Hullo, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ALEXANDER
dialogues.text: Good evening, sir.

dialogues.speaker: RUBINSTEIN
dialogues.text: Frank.

dialogues.speaker: DOLIN
dialogues.text: So this is the young man?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: How do you do, sir?

dialogues.speaker: DOLIN
dialogues.text: Hullo.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Missus. Very pleased to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: RUBINSTEIN
dialogues.text: Hullo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you forgive us for coming over at this ungodly hour, but we heard from Frank that you were in some trouble so we came over to see if we could be of any help.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Very kind of you, sir. Thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: DOLIN
dialogues.text: I understand that you had a rather unfortunate encounter with the Police tonight.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. I suppose you might call it that, sir.

dialogues.speaker: DOLIN
dialogues.text: Hahaha, and how are you feeling now?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Much better, thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: DOLIN
dialogues.text: Feel like talking to us. Answering a few questions?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Fine, sir, fine.

dialogues.speaker: DOLIN
dialogues.text: Well, as I've said, we've heard about you. We are interested in your case. We want to help you.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Thank you very much, sir.

dialogues.speaker: DOLIN
dialogues.text: But first we'd like to find out a few things about you.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: What would you like to know, sir?

dialogues.speaker: DOLIN
dialogues.text: Well, shall we get down to it?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Rubinstein takes out a notebook.

dialogues.speaker: RUBINSTEIN
dialogues.text: The newspapers mentioned that in addition to your being conditioned against acts of sex and violence, you've inadvertently been conditioned against music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, er, I think that was something that they hadn't planned for, you see, Missus, I'm very fond of music and always have been, especially Beethoven, Ludwig van... Beethoven. B... E... E... He leans over and looks at her writing in notebook.

dialogues.speaker: RUBINSTEIN
dialogues.text: It's alright, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: And it just so happened that while they were showing me a particularly bad film, of like a concentration camp, the background music was playing Beethoven.

dialogues.speaker: RUBINSTEIN
dialogues.text: So now you have the same reaction to music as you do to sex and violence?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Oh well, it's... it's not all music you see, Missus. It's just the 9th.

dialogues.speaker: RUBINSTEIN
dialogues.text: You mean Beethoven's 9th Symphony?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: That's right. Er... I can't listen to the 9th any more at all. When I hear the 9th, I get like this funny feeling.

dialogues.speaker: RUBINSTEIN
dialogues.text: When you say this funny feeling, you mean the state of mind brought on by the treatment they gave you?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: That is correct, sir. And then all I can think about is like trying to snuff it.

dialogues.speaker: RUBINSTEIN
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Snuff it, sir... um... death, I mean, missus... Er... I just want to die peacefully like with no... pain.

dialogues.speaker: RUBINSTEIN
dialogues.text: Do you feel that way now?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Um... oh no, sir, not exactly, I still feel very miserable, very much down in spirits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you still feel suicidal?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Um... well, put it this way... I feel very low in myself. I can't see much in the future, and I feel that any second something terrible is going to happen to me. He pitches forward, face into the plate of spaghetti.

dialogues.speaker: RUBINSTEIN
dialogues.text: Well done, Frank. Julian, get the car, will you please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexander sits looking up. Rubinstein, Julian and Dolin a listening to Beethoven played loudly on tape recorder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 9th Symphony booming up through the floor. Alex slowly regains consciousness.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I woke up. The pain and sickness all over me like an animal. Then I realised what it was. The music coming up from the floor was our old friend, Ludwig van and the dreaded 9th Symphony. He staggers to the door. It is locked. He kicks and tugs

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Open the door... turn it off... turn it off.

dialogues.speaker: THE BILLIARD ROOM BELOW
dialogues.text: Hi-Fi gear laid out on the table. Large speakers facing u Mr. Alexander trembles and twitches. He is now completely others merely wait, coolly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex on his knees. His hands cupped over his ears, bangin head on the floor. Then he stops and slowly straightens up, staring at the w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly I viddied what I had to do, and what I had wanted to do - and that was to do myself in, to snuff it, to blast off forever out of this wicked cruel world. One moment of pain perhaps and then sleep - forever and ever and ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex leaps out of the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex in bed. Camera slowly tracks along length of his bod Everything is bandages and plaster splints, wire cages, b drips.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I jumped, O my brothers, and I fell hard but I did not snuff it, oh no. if I had snuffed it, I would not be here to tell what I have told. I came back to life, after a long, black, black gap of what might have been a million years. We hear Alex moan, and then another moan. Alex and the ot few times. Suddenly, some curtains which have been drawn around anot in the ward are parted, and a nurse hurries to Alex, hast buttoning up her uniform. She is trailed by a young Inter fumbling with his trousers.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Oh, he's recovered conscienceness, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Em and Pee sitting around the bed.

dialogues.speaker: PEE
dialogues.text: Hullo, lad.

dialogues.speaker: EM
dialogues.text: Hullo, son, how are you?

dialogues.speaker: PEE
dialogues.text: Are you feeling better?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: What gives, O myee P and Em, what makes you think you are welcome? Em sobs. Pee comforts her.  Em sobs.

dialogues.speaker: PEE
dialogues.text: There, there mother, it's alright. He doesn't mean it. You were in the papers again, son. It said they had done great wrong to you. It said how the Government drove you to try and do yourself in... and when you think about it, son... maybe it was our fault too in a way... your home's your home when it's all said and done, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Psychiatrist wheels trolley to Alex's bed. He is sitting

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Good morning, Missus.

dialogues.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
dialogues.text: How are you feeling today?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Fine. Fine.

dialogues.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Good. I'm doctor Taylor.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I haven't seen you before.

dialogues.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
dialogues.text: I'm your Psychiatrist.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Psychiatrist? Huh, do I need one?

dialogues.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Just part of hospital routine.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: What are we going to do? Talk about me sex life?

dialogues.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
dialogues.text: No... I'm going to show you some slides and you are going to tell me what you think about them Alright?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Ohhh... jolly good. Perhaps you can explain me something to me first.

dialogues.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, when I was all like ashamed up and half awake and unconscious like, I kept having this dream like all these doctors were playing around with me gulliver. You know... like the inside of me brain. I seemed to have this dream over and over again. D'you think it means anything?

dialogues.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Patients who've sustained the kind of injuries you have often have dreams of this sort. It's all part of the recovery process.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Now then, each of these slides needs a reply from one of the people in the picture. You'll tell me what you think the person would say. Alright?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Righty, right. The doctor reads aloud the dialogue printed in the cartoo - a peacock. Alex laughs.

dialogues.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Isn't the plumage beautiful?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I just say what the other person would say?

dialogues.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes, well don't think about it too long, just say the first thing that pops into your mind.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Right... Knickers... Cabbages... It doesn't have a beak. Slide of woman speaking to boy.

dialogues.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Good. The boy you alway quarrelled with is seriously ill.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: That's right and I'll smash your face for you, yarblockos. Slide of watch shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. It wa your fault... you sold me a crummy watch. I want my money back.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Bollocks. You know what you can do with that watch? You can stick it up your arse. Slide of nude woman in bed, a man at the window.

dialogues.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Good. What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Excuse me, missus. No time for the old in- out, I've just come to read the meter. Slide of bird's nest with eggs.

dialogues.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Good. You can do whatever you like with these.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Eggiwegs. I would like to smash 'em. Pick up th elot and f... owww... He slams his hand down and cries out with pain.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Fucking hell...

dialogues.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Fine. Well, that's all there is to it. Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I hope so. Is that the end then?

dialogues.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I was quite enjoying that.

dialogues.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Good. I'm glad

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: How many did I get right?

dialogues.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
dialogues.text: It's not that kind of a test. But you seem well on the way to a complete recovery.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: And when do I get out of here then?

dialogues.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
dialogues.text: I'm sure it won't be long now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex sitting up, being fed by Nurse.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: So I waited and, O my brothers, I got a lot better munching away at eggiwegs, and lomticks of toast and lovely steakiweaks and then, one day, they said I was going to have a very special visitor. Doctor enters followed by Minister and Matron.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: Good evening, my boy.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Hi, hi, hi there, my little droogies.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Well, how are you getting on today, young man?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Great, sir. Great.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Can I do anything more for you , Minister?

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: I don't think so, Sir Leslie. Thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
dialogues.text: Then I'll leave you to it. Nurse. They exit. Minister moves to Alex.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: You seem to have a whole ward to yourself, my boy.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, and a very lovely place it is too, sir, when I wake up in the middle of the night with my pain.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: Yes... well good to see you on the mend. I've kept in constant touch with the hospital, of course, and now I've come to see you personally to see how you're getting along.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: I've suffered the tortures of the damned. The tortures of the damned, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes I can... Oh look, let me do that for you, shall I?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: I can tell you that I... and the Government of which I am a member are deeply sorry about this, my boy. Deeply sorry. We tried to help you. We followed recommendations had been made to us that turned out to be wrong. An enquiry will place the responsibility where it belongs. We want you to regard us as friends. We've put you right, you're getting the best of treatments. We never wished you harm, but there are some that did and do, and I think you know who those are. There are certain people who wanted to use you for political ends. People who would have been glad to have you dead because then they would have been able to blame it all on the Governement. I think you know who those are. There is also a certain man - a writer of subversive literature - who has been howling for your blood. He's been mad with desire to stick a knife into you, but you're safe from him now, we've put him away. He found out that you had done wrong to him - at least he believed you had done wrong. He had formed this idea in his head that you had been responsible for the death of someone near and dear to him. We put him away for his own protection... I'm sorry, I thought you were ready.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Where is he now, sir?

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: We put him away where he can do you no harm. You see we are looking after your interests. We are interested in you, and when you leave here you will have no further worries. We shall see to everything... a good job on a good salary.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: What job and how much?

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: You must have an interesting job at a salary which you would regard as adequate. Not only for the job which you are going to do and in compensation for what you believe you have suffered, but also because you are helping us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helping you, sir?

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: We always help our friends, don't we? (smiles) It is no secret that the Government has lost a lot of popularity because of you, my boy. There are some that think that at the next election we shall be out. The press has chosen to take a very unfavorable view of what we tried to do.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Well, who can bame them, sir?

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: Mmmm, possibly. Yes. But public opinion has a way of changing and you, Alex, if I may call you, Alex?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Certainly, sir. What do they call you at home?

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: My name is Frederick. As I was saying, Alex, you can be instrumental in changing the public verdict. Do you understand, Alex? Have I made myself clear?

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: As an unmuddied lake, Fred. As clear as an azurw sky of deepest summer. You can rely on me, Fred.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: Good... good boy. Oh yes, I understand you're fond of music. I have arranged a little surprise for you.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Surprise?

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: One I think you will like... as a, how shall I put it, as a symbol of our new understanding. An understanding between two friends.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX
dialogues.text: Thank you, Fred. Thank you. Minister turns and signals. Door opens and a crowd of cameramen and reporters rush in Aides push two 6-foot loudspeakers and a Hi-Fi on a troll

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what do you know, my brothers and only friends, it was the 9th, the glorious 9th of Ludwig van. Oh, it was gorgeosity and yummy yum yum. I was cured.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: As the music came to ist climax, I could viddy myself very clear, running and running on like very light and mysterious feet, carving the whole face of the creeching world with my cut throat britva. I was cured all right.
